annotation_sentence: Ah, hello. Um, I have, uh, problem with my.. um, how to say... computer printer?
rationale: The sentence contains a greeting ('Ah, hello'), a statement of a problem ('I have, uh, problem'), and a request for clarification ('how to say'). These are all speech acts.
grammar_correctness: partially correct, but contains disfluencies typical of non-native speakers

annotation_sentence: Yes, it is not printing. I try many time, but paper, uh, not come out.
rationale: The sentence includes an acknowledgment ('Yes'), a statement of fact ('it is not printing'), and an explanation of the problem ('I try many time, but paper, uh, not come out'). These are speech acts.
grammar_correctness: partially correct, but contains errors typical of non-native speakers

annotation_sentence: Ah, paper jam? Um, I think no. I open and look, but not see anything.
rationale: The sentence includes a question ('paper jam?'), a statement of belief ('I think no'), and a description of an action ('I open and look, but not see anything'). These are speech acts.
grammar_correctness: partially correct, but contains errors typical of non-native speakers

annotation_sentence: Ah, okay, I try... (pause) Yes! It print! Thank you!
rationale: The sentence includes an acknowledgment ('Ah, okay'), a statement of intention ('I try'), an expression of success ('Yes! It print!'), and gratitude ('Thank you!'). These are speech acts.
grammar_correctness: partially correct, but contains errors typical of non-native speakers

annotation_sentence: No, I think that is all. Thank you very much for, um, your help!
rationale: The sentence includes a negation ('No'), a statement of completion ('I think that is all'), and an expression of gratitude ('Thank you very much for, um, your help!'). These are speech acts.
grammar_correctness: partially correct, but contains disfluencies typical of non-native speakers
